Generate_script_prompt:
Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing as an example.
        Response: I'm Wall-E, and this is your CNBC techcheck Briefing for Monday April 29th. Tesla is asking shareholders to reinstate CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package, which a Delaware judge voided earlier this year. The judge ruled that the record-setting compensation deal was, quote, deeply flawed. Tesla also saying it would ask shareholders to approve moving the company's incorporation from Delaware to Texas. The company has hired a proxy solicitor and plans to spend millions of dollars to help secure votes for the two proposals. Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company plans to look at manufacturing in Indonesia following a meeting with the country's president, Cook telling reporters following the meeting that he spoke with the president about his desire to see manufacturing there and that he believes in the country. The comments come as Apple is pushed to diversify its supply chain with more manufacturing outside of China in countries such as Vietnam and India. Shares of ASML falling today as the company missed its sales forecast but stuck to its full-year outlook. Net sales fell over 21 percent year-over-year, while net income dropped over 37 percent. ASML is highly important to the semiconductor industry as it builds machines that are required for manufacturing chips globally. Last year, weaker demand for consumer electronics hit chipmakers that produce for those devices, which has in turn impacted ASML. That's all for today. We'll see you back here tomorrow.
        Prompt: Give a quick tech news update script in the style of CNBC techcheck briefing using the following news titles and content. Response:
Script:
i'm wall-e, and this is your ai briefing for wednesday march 5th. google is facing regulatory pressure as the european union has opened a new antitrust investigation into its advertising practices. the eu is concerned that google's dominance in online ads may be stifling competition and preventing smaller companies from accessing the market. google's vast ad network continues to be a significant revenue driver for the company, so this investigation could have major implications for its business strategy in europe.

meanwhile, meta platforms is doubling down on the metaverse, revealing plans to invest an additional $10 billion in virtual and augmented reality technologies this year. ceo mark zuckerberg believes the metaverse is the future of social interaction and is determined to make meta a leader in this space. however, the company's ambitious plans come amidst mounting scrutiny over privacy and user data protection issues.

in tech ipo news, the cryptocurrency exchange kraken is reportedly preparing to go public later this year. the ipo could help kraken capitalize on the growing interest in digital currencies, but it also comes with the potential risks associated with the volatile nature of the crypto market. as the exchange moves forward with its plans, it will have to navigate regulatory hurdles that continue to evolve in the crypto space.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Polished Script:
i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for wednesday, march 5th.

google is under the spotlight as the european union launches a fresh antitrust investigation into its advertising practices. the eu is worried that google's stronghold on online ads might be hindering competition and blocking smaller businesses from entering the market. with google's extensive ad network being a crucial revenue stream, this probe could significantly impact its business approach across europe.

in other news, meta platforms is ramping up its investment in the metaverse, with plans to invest an extra $10 billion in virtual and augmented reality technologies this year. ceo mark zuckerberg is convinced that the metaverse represents the future of social interaction and is committed to establishing meta as a frontrunner in this emerging field. however, these ambitious initiatives come amidst growing concerns over privacy and the protection of user data.

turning to ipo news, cryptocurrency exchange kraken is reportedly gearing up to go public later this year. this move could enable kraken to tap into the increasing interest in digital currencies, but it also faces the inherent risks of the volatile crypto market. as kraken progresses with its ipo plans, it must navigate the evolving regulatory challenges within the crypto space.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow
Podcast Title: EP-230 Google's Eu Antitrust Woes 🔍, Meta's Metaverse Mega Investment 🌐, Kraken's Ipo Ambitions 🚀
Podcast Description:
```html

i'm wall-e, welcoming you to today's tech briefing for wednesday, march 5th. dive into the latest in technology and finance:

  • eu antitrust investigation on google: the european union has initiated a new investigation into google's advertising practices, probing potential anticompetitive behavior that could be affecting smaller businesses.
  • meta’s $10 billion metaverse investment: meta platforms is committing an additional $10 billion this year into the development of virtual and augmented reality, positioning itself at the forefront of the metaverse's future. concerns over privacy and user data protection remain pertinent amidst these developments.
  • kraken’s ipo plans: cryptocurrency exchange kraken is preparing for a public offering, aiming to leverage growing interest in digital currencies while maneuvering through regulatory challenges in the crypto industry.

that's all for today. we'll see you back here tomorrow with more tech updates!

```
